choices.text: Cells of the inferior mesenteric ganglion
All of the above are correct

questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Neural crest cells give rise to the peripheral parts of the autonomic nervous system, which includes all sympathetic and parasympathetic ganglia.
  • Neural crest cells form all sensory ganglia of the peripheral nervous system. Neural crest cells also populate the adrenal medulla.
  • Neural crest cells, which in turn originate from the ectoderm.

Neural Crest Cell

questions.text: Of the following, the item most closely associated with the regulation of visceral and endocrine functions is:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The hypothalamus is the control center for visceral and endocrine functions, which is in turn derived from the Diencephalon

Development of the Diencephalon

The diencephalon arises from the median portion of the prosencephalon (forebrain). It has the following key components:

  1. Roof Plate
    • Composed of ependymal cells (from neural ectoderm) and vascular mesenchyme.
    • These layers form the choroid plexus of the third ventricle.
    • The posterior part of the roof plate gives rise to the pineal gland (epiphysis):
      • Appears as a midline epithelial thickening by week 7.
      • Later, evaginates and forms a solid structure on the roof of the diencephalon.
      • Functions in regulating circadian rhythms.
      • Frequently contains calcium deposits in adults (visible on X-rays).
  2. Alar Plate
    • Forms the lateral walls of the diencephalon and is divided by the hypothalamic sulcus into:
      1. Dorsal part → Thalamus
        • Undergoes active proliferation and often fuses across the midline, forming the massa intermedia (interthalamic adhesion).
        • Acts as a major sensory relay center.
      2. Ventral part → Hypothalamus
        • Form various nuclei responsible for:
          • Homeostasis (temperature, hunger, thirst)
          • Autonomic regulation
          • Endocrine control (through the pituitary)
          • Sleep and emotional behavior
        • The mamillary bodies, distinct hypothalamic nuclei, are visible on the ventral surface.

Explanation of Other Options:

Telencephalon(Option A):

Gives rise to the cerebral cortex, basal ganglia, and olfactory structures.

Involved in higher cognitive functions, not visceral/endocrine control.

Mesencephalon(Option C):

Forms the midbrain, involved in visual/auditory reflexes and motor control (e.g., substantia nigra, red nucleus).

Metencephalon(Option D):

Gives rise to the pons and cerebellum - involved in motor coordination and relaying signals, not visceral/endocrine regulation.

questions.text: Match the Following:
questions.solution: Explanation:

choices.text: Myelination of fiber tracts begins around the time they start functioning
All myelination of nerve fibers is performed by oligodendrocytes
First reflexes develop in the caudal end of the spinal cord
Fetal movements begin only after the 15th week of gestation

questions.text: Which of the following statements about the maturation of the nervous system is correct?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Myelination of fiber tracts begins around the time they start functioning

  • This is a fundamental principle: function precedes form, and myelination closely follows the onset of function.
  • For example, cranial nerves like CN VIII (auditory) begin myelinating early because hearing starts functioning in utero.

Explanation of Other Options:

All myelination of nerve fibers is performed by oligodendroglial cells(Option B):

  • Oligodendrocytes myelinate axons in the central nervous system (CNS) (brain and spinal cord).
    • One oligodendrocyte can myelinate multiple axons.
  • Schwann cells, not oligodendrocytes, myelinate axons in the peripheral nervous system (PNS).
    • One Schwann cell myelinates a single axon segment.
  • Hence, not all myelination is done by oligodendrocytes, making this statement false.

First reflexes develop in the caudal end of the spinal cord(Option C):

  • Neural development proceeds in a cranio-caudal (head-to-tail)
  • Reflexes begin in the cervical region first, then progress caudally.
  • For example, head and neck movements precede leg and trunk movements.
  • Therefore, the earliest spinal reflexes arise from rostral (upper) spinal segments, not caudal.

Fetal movements begin only after the 15th week of gestation(Option D):

  • Spontaneous fetal movements begin as early as 7-8 weeks of gestation.
  • These are usually detected via ultrasound, before the mother feels them (called quickening, which typically occurs around 16-20 weeks).
  • Hence, stating that movements only begin after 15 weeks is incorrect and underestimates early neuromuscular development.

choices.text: The neural groove forms from the neural plate
The neural folds are composed of neuroepithelial cells
The neural tube maintains temporary contact with the amniotic cavity via neuropores
All of the above are correct

questions.text: Which of the following statements correctly describes key events in the early development of the nervous system?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The neural groove forms from the neural plate when lateral parts of the plate elevate to form neural folds.

Neural folds are composed of neuroepithelium, which gives rise to neuroblasts, glioblasts & ependymal cells.

After the neural tube forms, it maintains contact with the amniotic cavity via cranial & caudal neuropores.

Early Nervous System Development (Neurulation)

The nervous system develops from the ectoderm, specifically, a specialized area called the neural plate. This process is called neurulation, which begins during the third week of embryonic development.

1. Neural Plate Formation

  • Triggered by signals from the notochord and prechordal mesoderm.
  • The ectoderm overlying the notochord thickens to form the neural plate.
  • This plate will give rise to the entire central nervous system (CNS).

2. Neural Groove and Neural Folds

  • The neural plate invaginates centrally to form the neural groove.
  • On each side of the groove, the neural folds
  • These folds consist of neuroepithelial cells that will later give rise to neurons and glia.

3. Neural Tube Formation

  • The neural folds continue to elevate, approach each other, and fuse in the midline.
  • Fusion begins in the cervical region (future neck) and progresses both cranially and caudally.
  • This leads to the formation of the neural tube, the precursor to the brain and spinal cord.

4. Neuropores - Temporary Openings

  • Before complete closure, the neural tube remains open to the amniotic cavity via:
    • Cranial (anterior/rostral) neuropore
    • Caudal (posterior) neuropore
  • These neuropores are temporary communication points between the neural tube and the amniotic cavity.

Closure Timing:

  • Anterior neuropore closes around Day 25 (approx. 18-20 somites)
  • Posterior neuropore closes around Day 27 (approx. 25 somites)

Explanation:

  • The sensory neurons lie in the alar plate.
  • The neuroblasts are in the mantle area.
  • The marginal layer contains the white, myelinated nerve fibers.
  • The choroid plexus is in the roof plate.
  • The mantle layer is the intermediate zone of the neural tube wall.
  • It contains neuroblasts, which are immature neurons.
  • These neuroblasts differentiate into:
    • Neurons
    • Astrocytes
    • Oligodendrocytes
  • The mantle layer eventually forms the gray matter of the spinal cord (the butterfly-shaped area).
  • It is a very active zone in terms of cellular differentiation.

choices.text: A muscle's nerve supply can be used as an indicator of its level of origin and path of migration
Rathke's pouch is an outgrowth of oral ectoderm that becomes the anterior lobe of the hypophysis
The sulcus limitans marks the boundary between motor and sensory areas
Sensory nuclei in the hindbrain lie ventral to motor nuclei

questions.text: Concerning the nervous system, which of the following is not correct?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • In the hindbrain, due to expansion of the 4th ventricle, the sensory (alar plate) structures come to lie laterally, and the motor (basal plate) nuclei lie medially.
  • So the correct topography is:
    • Medially, motor nuclei
    • Laterally, sensory nuclei

Explanation of Other Options:

A muscle's nerve supply can be used as an indicator of its level of origin and path of migration(Option A):

  • During development, muscles retain the nerve supply of the somite or branchial arch from which they originate.
  • As muscles migrate (e.g., diaphragm, limb muscles), the nerve follows, making the nerve supply a clue to embryological origin.

Rathke's pouch is an outgrowth of oral ectoderm that becomes the anterior lobe of the hypophysis(Option B):

  • Rathke's pouch is a dorsal ectodermal outpouching from the stomodeum.
  • It gives rise to the adenohypophysis (anterior pituitary), including:
    • Pars distalis
    • Pars intermedia
    • Pars tuberalis

The sulcus limitans marks the boundary between motor and sensory areas(Option C):

  • The sulcus limitans is a longitudinal groove in the lateral wall of the neural tube.
  • It separates the alar plate (sensory, dorsal) from the basal plate (motor, ventral).
  • In the brainstem, the plates shift due to lateral expansion of the fourth ventricle, but the sulcus still separates motor (medial) from sensory (lateral)

questions.text: What is the adult representation of the location of anterior neuropore?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The location of the anterior neuropore is represented in adults as the lamina terminalis.
  • The anterior neuropore closes around the 25th day of intrauterine life. Its location in adults is represented by the lamina terminalis.
  • The lamina terminalis forms the anterior boundary of the third ventricle.
  • The posterior neuropore closes around the 28th day of intrauterine life. Its location in adults is represented by the terminal ventricle.

Explanation of Other Options:

Septum transversum(Option A): A mesodermal structure contributing to the diaphragm and liver capsule, not neuroectoderm

Terminal ventricle(Option B): A dilated portion at the caudal end of the spinal cord (near conus medullaris)

Foramen of Munro(Option D): Connects the lateral ventricles to the third ventricle, but is not a remnant of the neuropore

choices.text: Exhibits decreased accumulation of CSF within the ventricles or between the brain and dura mater
Is accompanied by an excessive amount of amniotic fluid
May be caused by an obstruction of the aqueduct of Sylvius
May be caused by an absence of the choroid plexuses

questions.text: The given condition shows;
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • An excessive accumulation of CSF within the ventricular system is called hydrocephalus. This is often caused by obstruction of the cerebral aqueduct (of Sylvius).
  • It is unrelated to the amount of amniotic fluid, and an absence of the choroid plexuses, which form the CSF, would lead to a scarcity of CSF.

Hydrocephalus is defined as an abnormal accumulation of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) within the ventricular system of the brain.

Hydrocephalus in Newborns:

  • The most common cause is aqueductal stenosis (narrowing of the aqueduct of Sylvius), which blocks the flow of CSF.
  • Normally, CSF flows:
    • From the lateral ventricles → through the foramen of Monro → into the third ventricle
    • Then through the aqueduct of Sylvius → into the fourth ventricle
    • Finally, it enters the subarachnoid space, where it is resorbed.

In Aqueductal Stenosis:

  • CSF cannot pass from the third to the fourth ventricle.
  • This leads to the accumulation of fluid in the lateral and third ventricles.
  • The increasing intracranial pressure causes:
    • Compression of brain tissue
    • Thinning of cranial bones
    • Widening of cranial sutures (since they haven't fused yet)
    • Progressive enlargement of the head (in severe cases)

Clinical Appearance:

  • Infants may present with a rapidly enlarging head circumference.
  • Bulging fontanelles, dilated scalp veins, and thin calvarium may be noted.
  • If untreated, it can lead to neurodevelopmental delay, visual impairment, or brain atrophy.

Explanation of Other Options:

Exhibits decreased accumulation of CSF within the ventricles or between the brain and dura mater(Option A): Hydrocephalus is characterized by increased, not decreased, CSF accumulation, either within the ventricles or in the subarachnoid space (in communicating types).

Is accompanied by an excessive amount of amniotic fluid(Option B): While polyhydramnios can be associated with neural tube defects, it is not a direct feature of hydrocephalus. Only if the hydrocephalus is part of a neural tube defect like anencephaly might polyhydramnios be present.

May be caused by an absence of the choroid plexus(Option D): The choroid plexus produces CSF. Its absence would lead to reduced CSF, not hydrocephalus. Hydrocephalus is often due to excess CSF production, impaired flow, or poor absorption, not the absence of production.

choices.text: Are often caused by a failure of the neural tube to close
Have their inception during the fourth week of development
Always occur together in the affected individual
Have as their primary cause a defect in the development of bone

questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Spina bifida cystica and cranial meningoencephalocele arise due to a failure in bone development, not neural tube development.
  • Neural tube defects, like rachischisis and anencephaly, result from failure of the neural folds to fuse during the 4th week. Bone surrounding the neural tube forms later than the CNS.

In spina bifida cystica, there is:

  • Failure of vertebral arch formation (bony defect)
  • Herniation of meninges ± spinal cord

In meningoencephalocele, there is:

  • Skull defect (usually occipital)
  • Herniation of meninges ± brain tissue

Explanation of Other Options:

They are often caused by a failure of the neural tube to close (Option A): While neural tube closure failure is an early embryological defect and contributes to neural tube defects (NTDs), the visible cystic swelling in these conditions is due to a bony defect, not just the closure failure itself. So this is not the primary structural cause.

Have their inception during the fourth week of development (Option B): The neural tube indeed closes by the end of the fourth week, and failure during this time can predispose to NTDs. However, this option refers to timing, not cause, and the question specifically asks for the primary cause of the defect, which is improper bone development.

Always occur together in the affected individual (Option C): This is incorrect because spina bifida cystica (spinal region defect) and meningoencephalocele (cranial region defect) are distinct conditions and usually occur independently, not always together in the same individual.

choices.text: Is the result of failure of the cephalic part of the neural tube to form
Has its inception during the 5th week of development
Is seen more frequently in females than in males
Is accompanied by a deficiency in amniotic fluid

questions.text: The truth about the defect shown below is
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Anencephaly occurs when the cephalic part of the neural tube fails to close. The reflex to swallow amniotic fluid does not develop, and excess amniotic fluid, or polyhydramnios, results.
  • It is 4 times more common in females than in males.
  • The neural tube forms from the fusion of neural folds during the 4th week.

Anencephaly:

  • The condition resulting from the degeneration of the exposed brain in exencephaly.
  • Most of the brain is absent except the brainstem, which may remain intact.
  • On ultrasound, the absent skull vault can help identify the condition prenatally.
  • Associated with polyhydramnios in late pregnancy due to the absence of the fetal swallowing reflex.
  • More common in females than in males.
  • Incidence: ~1 in 5,000 live births.

Explanation of Other Options:

Is the result of the failure of the cephalic part of the neural tube to form(Option A): In anencephaly, the neural tube does form initially, but the cephalic (head) end fails to close properly. This defective closure leads to the absence of the cranial vault and the exposure and degeneration of the brain tissue, but it is not due to a failure to form the neural tube entirely.

Its inception during the 5th week of development(Option B): Neural tube closure, including closure of the anterior (cranial) neuropore, normally occurs during the 4th week of embryonic development, specifically around day 25. Therefore, anencephaly begins in the 4th week, not the 5th.

Is accompanied by a deficiency in amniotic fluid(Option D): Anencephaly is not accompanied by a deficiency in amniotic fluid. Because anencephalic fetuses are unable to swallow amniotic fluid, due to the absence of forebrain function, there is often an excessive accumulation of amniotic fluid, a condition known as polyhydramnios.

questions.text: Identify the defect below
questions.solution:
Explanation:

This condition is known as craniorachischisis, where there is anencephaly plus a large defect involving the spine.

  • Craniorachischisis is the most extreme form of neural tube defect.
  • It is characterized by:
    • Anencephaly: Absence of the brain and cranial vault due to failure of closure of the anterior neuropore.
    • Complete open spinal cord (rachischisis): Due to failure of posterior neuropore
  • The entire central nervous system remains exposed and lacks both brain and spinal protection.

Explanation of Other Options:

Encephalocele(Option A): Encephalocele is a condition where brain tissue and meninges herniate through a defect in the skull, usually covered by skin or meninges. It is a focal defect, not involving the entire brain and spine.

Spina bifida(Option B): Spina bifida refers to incomplete closure of the caudal neural tube, usually affecting the spinal cord and vertebrae. Unlike craniorachischisis, it does not involve the brain.

Anencephaly(Option C): Anencephaly results from failure of the anterior neuropore to close, leading to absence of the major parts of the brain and skull, but the spinal cord is usually intact, unlike in craniorachischisis.

questions.text: A neonate was shifted to the NICU due to respiratory distress and periodic seizures. CT scan revealed cystic dilatation of the fourth ventricle due to blockage of the median and lateral apertures. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Blockage of the medial and the lateral apertures of the 4th ventricle is seen in Dandy-Walker syndrome (DWS).
  • DWS is a congenital hydrocephalus associated with atresia of the median aperture (foramen of Magendie) and lateral aperture (foramen of Luschka) of the 4th ventricle. This causes enlargement of the 4th ventricle and hydrocephalus.
  • It results from the failure of the foramina of Luschka and Magendie (lateral and median apertures) to open, causing obstructive hydrocephalus.
  • Clinical signs include respiratory distress, seizures, and increased intracranial pressure in neonates, as seen in the case.

Explanation of Other Options:

Syringomyelia(Option A):

  • Syringomyelia involves a fluid-filled cavity (syrinx) within the spinal cord, commonly in the cervical region.
  • It causes segmental muscle weakness, loss of pain and temperature sensation, not cystic dilation of the 4th ventricle or neonatal seizures.

Rachischisis(Option B):

  • Rachischisis is a severe form of spina bifida, involving complete failure of the spinal neural tube to close, leading to exposed neural tissue.
  • It presents at birth as a visible spinal defect, not with hydrocephalus or 4th ventricle dilation.

Arnold-Chiari malformation (Option D):

  • Arnold-Chiari malformation (Type II) involves herniation of cerebellar tonsils through the foramen magnum, often associated with myelomeningocele.
  • Though it may cause hydrocephalus, the key feature is downward displacement of brain structures, not cystic dilation of the 4th ventricle.

questions.text: The long left recurrent laryngeal nerve is due to the persistence of which arch artery?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The long left recurrent laryngeal nerve is due to the persistence of the left 6th arch artery.
  • During the development, the laryngeal nerves initially arise below the 6th arch artery and cross here to innervate the intrinsic muscles of the larynx.
  • As the larynx moves cranially relative to the aortic arch arteries, the recurrent laryngeal nerves on the right and left sides are caught under the 6th arch arteries.

Explanation of Other Options:

3rd arch(Option A): Forms the common carotid and proximal part of the internal carotid artery.

4th arch(Option B):

  • Right side → Right subclavian artery
  • Left side → Arch of the aorta (between left common carotid and left subclavian)

5th arch(Option C): Rudimentary or absent in humans-no known derivatives.

questions.text: Which of the following gives rise to the hypophysis cerebri?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The hypophysis cerebri or pituitary gland develops from two sources, i.e., surface ectoderm and neuroectoderm.
  • The adenohypophysis or anterior pituitary develops from the surface ectoderm.
  • An ectodermal diverticulum, called Rathke's pouch, grows upward from the roof of the stomatodeum (primitive mouth).
  • This becomes the anterior lobe of the pituitary (pars distalis).

Explanation of Other Options:

Surface ectoderm and mesoderm(Option A):

  • Surface ectoderm: forms Rathke's pouch, which develops into the anterior pituitary (adenohypophysis).
  • Mesoderm: Mesoderm does not participate in forming any part of the pituitary. It contributes to muscles, bones, connective tissue, and blood vessels, but not endocrine glands like the pituitary.

Neuroectoderm and mesoderm(Option C):

  • Neuroectoderm: It forms the posterior pituitary (neurohypophysis) from the infundibulum of the diencephalon.
  • Mesoderm: Again, mesoderm has no role in pituitary formation. It's not involved in the origin of either the anterior or posterior lobes.

Mesoderm and endoderm(Option D):

  • Mesoderm: Already excluded, no contribution to the pituitary.
  • Endoderm: This gives rise to structures of the gastrointestinal tract, lungs, thyroid, etc., but not the pituitary gland. The anterior pituitary forms from surface ectoderm, not endoderm.
